_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

                                                         EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

                                                         Yara North America, Inc.

                                                     Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal



Yara North America, Inc. Is a corporation wholly owned by Yara International, Inc  a global company  engaged in the production and shipping of ammonia, and fertilizer products.  The Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal is located about 1 mile west of U.S. Route 41 on Port Sutton Road and south of Tampa, Florida.  The facility receives anhydrous ammonia from ocean-going vessels, stores the ammonia at near atmospheric pressure, and transfers the ammonia to its customers via a pipeline (primarily) and trucks. The facility is situated on Port Sutton Channel, with dock facilities for one ship, and storage tanks with the capacity for up to 49,000 tons of ammonia.  The ammonia is in liquid form and is maintained at low temperature (-28? F) to keep the storage tank pressure below one pound per square inch.



POLLUTION PREVENTION POLICY:



Yara North America, Inc. is committed to protecting the environment and preserving our natural resources for future generations. We strive to eliminate or reduce our use of toxic substances and to minimize our use of energy and the generation of all wastes to the extent technically and economically feasible. We strive to minimize the generation of pollution at the source, but, where that cannot be achieved, we are committed to environmentally sound methods of recycling, treatment, and disposal. By preventing pollution at the source, we strive to achieve cost savings, increase operational efficiencies, and maintain a safe and healthy workplace.



REGULATED SUBSTANCE:



Anhydrous Ammonia is the only regulated substance at this facility subject to EPA Risk Management Program and the OSHA Process Safety Management Program. The termi

nal receives all of its ammonia via ships and transfers the ammonia out of the facility via a pipeline (owned by others) and tank trucks. The ammonia contains a small amount (0.20-0.50%) of water that serves as a corrosion inhibitor.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY:



The management and employees of this facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases. It is the personal challenge and policy of the management and associates of this facility to identify and reduce or eliminate all recognized process hazards.



To reduce or eliminate accidents and prevent accidental releases, the facility is committed to the following:



* A knowledgeable, highly trained, and motivated employee group.

* A well-designed facility that is state-of-the-art and that is maintained and operated in a superior manner.

* Improvements that enhance safety and accident prevention.

* Preparation and training for emergency response.



Yara North America, Inc. has always had a written Emergency Response Plan in effect, and all of its employees are trained to the extent of First Responder level for ammonia release emergencies. The plan is designed to prevent employee exposure and to coordinate with local emergency response agencies in the event of a release. A shared community and plant emergency siren system is in operation and tested on a monthly basis. This plan is coordinated with the local community response plan, and is available to those responding agencies. Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know information, as required under SARA Title III, has been provided to the State Emergency Response Commission, the Local Emergency Planning Committee, and the local fire department.



PREVENTION PROGRAM:



The Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal is subject to OSHA Process Safety Management Rule, and is therefore under the EPA Risk Management Rule. It is a Program 3 facility with a Program 3 Prevention Program. The OSHA PSM/EPA Prevention Progra

m consists of a set of facility management policies and procedures that promote and recognize process safety and the prevention of accidents in plants that handle, use, store, and process hazardous chemicals above the threshold quantity specified. The procedures address all aspects of facility activities, including training, maintenance, operating procedures, process reviews, safe work practices, incident investigation, audits, and other activities in a manner to provide controls to prevent errors, failures, and inadvertent changes in a process which could result in accidents.



The prevention program consists of many elements and policies, which are briefly outlined below.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION: Employees participate in all aspects of the program, and are provided with the information developed in the program.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION: All necessary process information and records are maintained in several convenient locations, including information on the hazards of the chemicals, process technology with safe operating limits, and equipment records and design requirements.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS: Contract employees, with extensive professional training in the methods of process hazard analysis (PHA), are retained to act as PHA team leaders and work in conjunction with the Terminal employees. These reviews are updated on a regular basis.



OPERATING PROCEDURES: Operating procedures are in place for all aspects of the operation, including emergency operation and shutdown.



OPERATIONS TRAINING: All operators receive initial training in the process and its operating procedures and are supervised by an experienced operator for a lengthy training period before being allowed to control the process on their own. They must pass written exams and demonstrate competency in all aspects of plant operation, including unexpected malfunctions.



CONTRACTORS: Contractor selection includes review of safety performance and programs.  Contractors are also required t

o have had recent site-specific training from the facility.  Periodic evaluations are made to assure that work is completed in a safe manner.



PRE-STARTUP REVIEW: A safety review is conducted on any new process equipment or any significant modification of the process.  This assures that construction and equipment installed are in accordance with design, that all necessary procedures, including safety procedures, are in place, that necessary training is completed, and that hazard analysis or other requirements of management of change are completed.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY: This is a quality assurance procedure to assure that equipment, parts, materials, and installations are suitable for the applications intended. Maintenance employees are trained in process hazards and safety procedures applicable to their work. Inspections, procedures, and testing are conducted under this part of the program.



SAFE WORK PRACTICES: Procedures and policies for all work permits and maintenance lockout/tagout procedures are in force, and are periodically reviewed for completeness and effectiveness.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE: No changes in the process or procedures are allowed without a review and authorization. Safety impacts, technical review, required procedure modifications, and training needed are all considered in this review.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION: A facility team promptly investigates any accident, near miss, or incident that resulted in, or could have resulted in, an ammonia release.  Findings of the investigation team and their recommendations for corrective action are documented, as is the resolution of the recommendations and corrective actions.



COMPLIANCE AUDIT: The program is audited at least every three years to verify compliance with these procedures. Findings of the audit are documented and any deficiencies are corrected and documented.



5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY: 



The Risk Management rule requires inclusion of the 5-year accident history of the facility for

all accidental releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or any known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. There have been no reportable releases in the facility's last five years. However, a non-reportable release was recorded on July 2, 2013, for which a notification was submitted to the National Response Center, case number 701976. This release was less than 100 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. 



SYNOPSIS OF WORST AND ALTERNATE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS:



The Risk Management rule requires a hazard analysis for worst case and alternate case accidental release scenarios for regulated substances. The rule requires an analysis involving the release of the total contents of the largest storage vessel of ammonia at this site. This is called the "worst case toxic release scenario" (worst case scenario) and involves the release of 32,250 tons of ammonia. This release must be considered to occur over a 10- minute period and pooling of the ammonia can be considered when modeling this release.  EPA?s RMP*COMP version 1.07 was used to determine the maximum downwind distance the ammonia release could impact the general public.  This assessment incorporated a toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L (Ammonia concentration) of 0.14 mg/L.  This toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L refers to the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual?s ability to take protective action.



An alternate scenario, which is a more likely event, is required to be submitted. The alternate case chosen involved the release of ammonia from a transfer pipe where 96,000 pounds would be released over a 2-minute period. A significantly lower quantity is involved because various shutdown safeguards have been installed and operat

or intervention will tend to mitigate and limit the quantity in such cases. The same modeling techniques were applied and resulted in much lesser off-site impact.  Under average weather conditions of low/moderate wind speed and neutral atmospheric dispersion, the release will cause off-site impacts.  The EPA?s RMP*COMP version 1.07, was also used to perform the off-site consequence analysis.  The ammonia toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L was used in the assessment.



CHANGES FOR SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS: 



Safety improvements are a continual and ongoing process at the Terminal.  The Prevention Program of the Process Safety Management Program facilitates this process.  Many process safeguards have been implemented as a result of the Process Hazard Analysis and the Incident Investigation activities.  The increased emphasis on security measures since September 11, 2001 has also been instrumental in many improvements, such as an expanded video surveillance system, improved fencing, all electronically controlled gates, intruder alarms, crash barriers, and greatly enhanced lighting.  Among the many improvements  for this facility are more security cameras, more radios, more ammonia sensors, an improved ship/shore emergency shutdown device, installation of quantifier/alarm systems on all Storage Tank vacuum/vent valves, the installation of a deluge vapor suppression system, upgrading of instrumentation, upgrading of compressor systems, the testing/repairing/painting/re-insulating of Terminal piping, and the institution of a Preventive Maintenance Program.  It is the belief of Yara North America, Inc. that through improvements like these and the diligent application of the elements of the Prevention Program/Process Safety Management Program that our employees and the community can be assured that the need for emergency response has been, and will continue to be, significantly diminished and hopefully will never be necessary.
